messageBody:
shefehs wrote:

> I've read all over the place that it's a bad idea to include multiple
> assertions in one test case, but it seems to me that sometimes it's
> very useful.

I call this a "Novice rule", thinking of the Dreyfus Model of Skills
Acquisition. I think of Novice rules this way: Novices should follow the
rules for these reasons:

* the rule is simple to express
* the rule is safe
* the rule teaches

Once you have learned a lot of what the rule teaches, you can progress
to the next levels with regards to that concept.

In this case, I find my designs improved when I wrote only one assertion
per test. Then I noticed the equivalence between one assertion and 'n'
assertions, as long as all the assertions came at the end of the test.
From that, I progressed to a new rule:

"Only one set of arrange, act, assert sections per test" (Google "Bill
Wake 3 A's" for more about arrange, act, assert.)

I followed this rule for a while, then I wrote this article:

http://articles.jbrains.ca/OneActPerTest.html

Since then, I have progressed to this new rule:

"You'd better have a damn good reason to have more than one 'act'
section per test."

The article helped me articulate one or two "damn good reason"s.
Nowadays, I consider myself an Expert (on the Dreyfus scale,
specifically), so I don't worry about the rules. I notice that I tend to
have only one 'act' section per test and that I tend to have only one
assertion per test, and I notice that my designs tend to be better the
more I pay attention to those two things, but I no longer consider them
rules I must follow.

I hope that helps.
